description: From Middle English party, partye, partie, from Anglo-Norman partie, from Medieval Latin partīta (“a part, party”), from Latin partīta, feminine of partītus, past participle of partior (“to divide”); see part. Doublet of partita.

entries.meaning: (law) A person or group of people constituting a particular side in a contract or legal action.
examples: The contract requires that the party of the first part pay the fee.

entries.meaning: With to: an accessory, someone who takes part.
examples: I can't possibly be a party to that kind of reckless behaviour.

definitionGroups.group: (now rare in general sense) A group of people forming one side in a given dispute, contest etc.

entries.meaning: (role-playing games, online gaming) Active player characters organized into a single group.
(video games) A group of characters controlled by the player.
(politics) A political group considered as a formal whole, united under one specific political platform of issues and campaigning to take part in government.
examples: The green party took 12% of the vote.

entries.meaning: (military) A discrete detachment of troops, especially for a particular purpose.
examples: The settlers were attacked early next morning by a scouting party.

definitionGroups.group: A group of persons collected or gathered together for some particular purpose.

entries.meaning: A gathering of usually invited guests for entertainment, fun and socializing.
examples: I'm throwing a huge party for my 21st birthday.

entries.meaning: A group of people traveling or attending an event together, or participating in the same activity.
examples: We're expecting a large party from the London office.
Do you have a table available for a party of four?

entries.meaning: A gathering of acquaintances so that one of them may offer items for sale to the rest of them.
A small group of birds or mammals.

verbs.description: party (third-person singular simple present parties, present participle partying, simple past and past participle partied)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To celebrate at a party, to have fun, to enjoy oneself.
examples: We partied until the early hours.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, slang, euphemistic) To take recreational drugs.
(intransitive) To engage in flings, to have one-night stands, to sow one's wild oats.
(online gaming, intransitive) To form a party (with).
examples: If you want to beat that monster, you should party with a healer.

description: From Middle English party, from Old French parti (“parted”), from Latin partītus (“parted”), past participle of partiri (“to divide”). More at part.

entries.meaning: Of a fence or wall: shared by two properties and serving to divide them.
(obsolete, except in compounds) Divided; in part.
(heraldry) Parted or divided, as in the direction or form of one of the ordinaries.
